clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Immediate and Delayed Closure of Type II and IIIa Open Tibia Fractures
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Study of Immediate and Delayed Closure of Type II and IIIa Open Tibia Fractures: A Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock: Delayed wound closure is considered by many to be the standard of care for the treatment of an open fracture. This study was conducted to determine the feasibility of a large multi-center prospective randomized clinical trial and collect the pilot data needed to compete for the funding for such a trial. The study was designed to compare immediate and delayed closure of Gustilo type II and IIIa tibia diaphyseal fractures. The primary outcomes were the infection rates and fracture related complications in patients treated with immediate or delayed wound closure strategies.

primary_outcome.description: defined as cases determined definitively by a positive culture or treated empirically based on tenderness, erythema, and heat at the wound site.
need for additional procedures and hospital readmissions related to the index injury will be documented
evidence of bridging callus on three of four cortices assessed by biplanar radiograph

clinical_study.condition: Type II and IIa Open Tibia Fractures

arm_group.description: wounds packed open with normal saline wet to dry gauze dressings and were returned to the operating room 36 to 72 hours after initial procedure for debridement and definitive closure.
traumatic and surgical wounds closed at initial surgical intervention

intervention.description: wounds packed open with normal saline wet to dry gauze dressings and were returned to the operating room 36 to 72 hours after initial procedure for a second debridement and definitive closure.
traumatic and surgical wounds closed at the initial surgical intervention

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Gustilo type II-IIIa tibia fracture
- age greater than 15 years
- fractures amenable to intramedullary nailing
Exclusion Criteria:
- excessive wound contamination
- patient cardio-pulmonary or hemodynamic instability preventing prompt surgical intervention
- impaired or absent consciousness
- refusal of consent
